solution:
We can expand the determinant as follows:
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 & -3 & 3 \\ 0 & 5 & -1 \\ 4 & -2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 5 & -1 \\ -2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - (-3) \begin{vmatrix} 0 & -1 \\ 4 & 1 \end{vmatrix} + 3 \begin{vmatrix} 0 & 5 \\ 4 & -2 \end{vmatrix} \\
&= ((5)(1) - (-1)(-2)) + 3 ((0)(1) - (-1)(4)) + 3 ((0)(-2) - (5)(4)) \\
&= \boxed{-45}.
\end{align*}We can also expand along the first column, to take advantage of the 0 in the first column, to get
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 & -3 & 3 \\ 0 & 5 & -1 \\ 4 & -2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 5 & -1 \\ -2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} + 4 \begin{vmatrix} -3 & 3 \\ 5 & -1 \end{vmatrix} \\
&= ((5)(1) - (-1)(-2)) + 4((-3)(-1) - (3)(5)) \\
&= \boxed{-45}.
\end{align*}
socratic_questions:
1. What is the definition of a determinant? Can you explain it in your own words?
2. How can you apply the expansion by minors method to find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix? 
3. Why do we expand the determinant along the first column in this case? 
4. Can you explain the steps involved in expanding the determinant of the given matrix using the cofactor expansion method?
5. How do you calculate the determinants of the 2x2 matrices involved in the expansion? Can you show an example calculation?
6. What are the signs associated with the various terms in the expansion? What is the pattern here?
7. Can you explain the significance of the -45 result? What does a determinant of -45 indicate about the matrix?
